comment: Black isn't threatening ...e5 to block the center and 3...d7-d5 4. exd5 exd5 5. d4 favors White because Pd5 is already targeted by Nc3.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake, as allowing Black to advance...e5 would have opened an avenue for Black to challenge White's central control with 3...d7-d5, and after 4. exd5 exd5, White's position would be weakened due to Black's central pawn on d5 being directly threatened by White's Nc3.
context: This is a game between Fedorov, A. (as White) and Miezis, N. (as Black). Last move played: White plays Knight to c3
reformulated: "Black doesn't pose any immediate threat on e5, and the 3...d7-d5 followed by 4. exd5 exd5 and 5. d4 gives White a significant advantage since the pawn on d5 is now attacked by White's knight on c3."

comment: Black can choose this variation without fear White could set up a Maroczy Bind (c2-c4 & e2-e4 together) because of 3. Nc3. It gives Black the flexibility to develop his other pieces after seeing where White's are.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake, as it identifies the potential pitfall of White's next move (Nc3) which could lead to a strong Maroczy Bind setup, exploiting Black's position.

reformulated: "Black's move is risky as it doesn't counter White's potential Maroczy Bind strategy with c2-c4 and e2-e4. White's choice of 3. Nc3 provides Black the chance to opt for this line without concern, allowing for flexible piece development."

comment: In the Almasi-Piket game White traded bishops and was able to play on the dark squares later. Here White forces a weakening of Black's king-side pawns, but Bc5 remains. Emanuel Lasker's general rule was to not (!) double a person's king-side pawns before he has castled because it opens the g-file for a rook. In this case Ke8 hasn't committed to staying on the king-side.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as trading bishops without casting first leaves Black's king-side pawns vulnerable and doesn't follow Emanuel Lasker's general rule.
moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 e6 3. Nc3 a6 4. d4 cxd4 5. Nxd4 Qc7 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. Be3 Nf6 8. O-O Nxd4 9. Bxd4 Bc5 10. Bxf6
context: This is a game between Fedorov, A. (as White) and Miezis, N. (as Black). Last move played: White plays Bishop takes on f6
reformulated: White's bishop trade resulted in a weakening of Black's king-side pawns. Double-checking the king-side pawns is crucial, as per Emanuel Lasker's advice; it's risky to open the g-file for a rook without castling first. Black, with Ke8, hasn't relocated their king-side pawns yet.

comment: How is White to proceed? If he advances e4-e5 (hoping a pawn exchange would open the f-file to his advantage) then fxe5 would discover an attack on Qh4. If White moves Qh4 first then ...b5-b4 would discoordinate White severely. It seems White needs more time, so 15. a3 seems necessary.
reasoning: The comment accurately identifies the potential issue with moving the pawn to e5 and provides a logical alternative to consider with 15. a3, suggesting that White may need more time to assess the situation properly.
